text: Yes March was my best month since September 2020

elements.text: Yes March was my best month since September 2020

text:
<@UUE6E1LA1> Sorry to hear about the health issues, hope you're on the mend soon. Its interesting about what you said about TPD (my best month is march too but not incorporating TPD). Ive had the feeds for a while now and whilst my normal bread and butter stuff is coming on leaps and bounds, I'm embarrassed to say that my TPD is yet to bear fruit. (In fact it hindered my results if anything)
I'm only recently been able to start recording the TPD data and building on that, but without giving away the crown jewels, could you give an idea about how you would approach modelling it in general?
We all work hard for our edges, so I dont expect you to give anything away as such, just a common sense approach and a sense of direction would help me! Thanks

elements.text:
Sorry to hear about the health issues, hope you're on the mend soon. Its interesting about what you said about TPD (my best month is march too but not incorporating TPD). Ive had the feeds for a while now and whilst my normal bread and butter stuff is coming on leaps and bounds, I'm embarrassed to say that my TPD is yet to bear fruit. (In fact it hindered my results if anything)
I'm only recently been able to start recording the TPD data and building on that, but without giving away the crown jewels, could you give an idea about how you would approach modelling it in general?
We all work hard for our edges, so I dont expect you to give anything away as such, just a common sense approach and a sense of direction would help me! Thanks

text: I've written a lot of software GUI tools that allow me to "replay" inplay data and this is where I have got most of my initial ideas from. All I am willing to say really is that I have not yet got what I suppose most of the other TPD guys here have (and what TPD sell to bookies) and that is a ML (or not ML) model that models a probability for each runner at each point in time. I have tried this but my knowledge of ML is just not advanced enough. What I have is more simple than that but in some ways also more complicated. That sounds strange probably but hard to explain further without giving the game away.

elements.text: I've written a lot of software GUI tools that allow me to "replay" inplay data and this is where I have got most of my initial ideas from. All I am willing to say really is that I have not yet got what I suppose most of the other TPD guys here have (and what TPD sell to bookies) and that is a ML (or not ML) model that models a probability for each runner at each point in time. I have tried this but my knowledge of ML is just not advanced enough. What I have is more simple than that but in some ways also more complicated. That sounds strange probably but hard to explain further without giving the game away.

text: I really want to throw multinomial logistic regression at it but I am not sure what the right approach is here as there are not a fixed amout of runners per race. I am comfortable with regular logistic regression but never actually performed multinomial. Any mathematicians here have any suggestions on how to use it on horses? Is partitioning the dataset into distinct sets that contain races with the same number of runners the way to go? Shame we can't get TPD and inplay markets on the dogs. Can you imagine the carnage there.....

text: To be honest a great part of dealing with the TPD data is actually coping with the numerous issues that crop up in the feed.

elements.text: To be honest a great part of dealing with the TPD data is actually coping with the numerous issues that crop up in the feed.

text: Thanks <@UUE6E1LA1> that's a starter. That first sentence resonates with me and that is the approach Im taking too. In a way, Im glad is a difficult nut to crack, just knowing its possible is enough to pursue it further. Thanks for the response

elements.text: Thanks

text: By great I don't mean "good" I mean important and time consuming.

elements.text: By great I don't mean "good" I mean important and time consuming.

text:
Yes thats what has threw me to be fair. Ive tried to smooth the data out by using moving averages etc it helped but slowed things down too much
If I could strip out the outliers that would make sense.

elements.text:
Yes thats what has threw me to be fair. Ive tried to smooth the data out by using moving averages etc it helped but slowed things down too much
If I could strip out the outliers that would make sense.

text: Yeah any kind of causal filter applied will generate lag. Its all tricky really and takes time to get used to. This is why I am not convinced that TPD buying out Betmover was the best idea in the world. Given some of the inaccuracies and issues with the data I can't see how manual traders are going to get much out of GPS

text: Two things <@UUE6E1LA1>. Firstly, I don't think you should put much stock in TPD's ML model. Secondly, regarding your uncertainty about different numbers of runners per race, you can just train different models for each number of runners

elements.text: Two things

. Firstly, I don't think you should put much stock in TPD's ML model. Secondly, regarding your uncertainty about different numbers of runners per race, you can just train different models for each number of runners

text: Yeah that was pretty much the only thing I could think of. Never used MLR in anger before so I will try it out. I've no idea if the TPD ML model is any good and its no use to me anyway but I was just aware of it and I would be surprised if they are the only one with such a model. I do know though that not everyone on here goes down the ML path

text: Mine's not ML (but it's not ifs either). One thing that might be a barrier to someone like you <@UUE6E1LA1> is the desire to get the maths right. Your maths doesn't need to be correct it just needs to return something useful most of the time.

elements.text: Mine's not ML (but it's not ifs either). One thing that might be a barrier to someone like you
is the desire to get the maths right. Your maths doesn't need to be correct it just needs to return something useful most of the time.

text: Yeah that is a very fair point <@UGV299K6H> . It's not so much about needing to be correct, just trying to map the right tool to the job - at least in the sense of the tools that I know about.

elements.text: Yeah that is a very fair point
. It's not so much about needing to be correct, just trying to map the right tool to the job - at least in the sense of the tools that I know about.

text: What I have now is crude compared with a ML or a statistical model and its doing ok. Maths is intersting and its useful but I'll not turn down profit because my approach is less sophisticated thats for sure.

elements.text: What I have now is crude compared with a ML or a statistical model and its doing ok. Maths is intersting and its useful but I'll not turn down profit because my approach is less sophisticated thats for sure.

text: Using the data you don’t need ML to work out a prediction on who is going to win, the trick is assigning an accuracy to this prediction mixed with execution (the most important and not just limited to getting matched) and as mentioned disregarding crappy data

elements.text: Using the data you don’t need ML to work out a prediction on who is going to win, the trick is assigning an accuracy to this prediction mixed with execution (the most important and not just limited to getting matched) and as mentioned disregarding crappy data

text: And yeah <@UBS7QANF3> lots of if statements :sunglasses:

lots of if statements

text: Yeah agreed. But I would really like to get a model that spits out probabilities of each runner winning given the current (and previous) states of the GPS info as this would give me a lot more confidence in my ask prices being value.

elements.text: Yeah agreed. But I would really like to get a model that spits out probabilities of each runner winning given the current (and previous) states of the GPS info as this would give me a lot more confidence in my ask prices being value.

text: Yeah I am not goint to try ML. I don't know enough about it. But I will try MLR as well as more nuts and bolts approaches. To be fair though I would probably be better off working on non TPD stuff. For me it feels like I have just learned to ride a bike for the first time and TPD acts like a pair of stabilisers on the back wheels!!!
